text: Hi freelancers! Do you charge for consultations with prospective new clients? If so, is it a normally hourly fee, or how do you work the pricing structure? Just curious as to what others are doing. I tend to keep my clients for a long time and haven’t thought much about how I want to move forward with consultations in the future, since I don’t need to do many.

elements.text: Hi freelancers! Do you charge for consultations with prospective new clients? If so, is it a normally hourly fee, or how do you work the pricing structure? Just curious as to what others are doing. I tend to keep my clients for a long time and haven’t thought much about how I want to move forward with consultations in the future, since I don’t need to do many.

text:
I provide as much information as possible on my website, hidden pricing page, and in messages so I rarely need a call with new clients.

If it's a _big_ job that's 95% going ahead then I'd agree a free call then wrap the time into the project. But honestly, I've never had to do that. Having as much templated as possible ahead of time has made me take 0 calls with prospects over the last 4 years.

text: This is quite a neat tool to charge for your time: <https://remotehour.com/> - if someone wants to "jump on a call" but you think they're a timewaster, then you can charge for how long they take up. It encourages people to be swift, or think twice about wasting your time. Helps filter out the time wasters.

attachments.text: Remotehour solves digital chats with a spontaneous, “open-door" online video call solution.
attachments.title: Online Office Hours Solution

elements.text: This is quite a neat tool to charge for your time:

- if someone wants to "jump on a call" but you think they're a timewaster, then you can charge for how long they take up. It encourages people to be swift, or think twice about wasting your time. Helps filter out the time wasters.

text: No way. I'm a really big fan of a relationship-based approach. I charge good rates, but I don't want people to feel like I'm nickel and diming them every time they talk to me. Building a good relationship with someone is worth far more than the few hundred measly bucks you could charge for a consultation call.

elements.text: No way. I'm a really big fan of a relationship-based approach. I charge good rates, but I don't want people to feel like I'm nickel and diming them every time they talk to me. Building a good relationship with someone is worth far more than the few hundred measly bucks you could charge for a consultation call.

text:
First informational call is always free. It’s about establishing fit on both sides so I don’t see it as giving away time. Agree with <@U02UNK9DJSZ>!!
However, I do try to learn enough beforehand over email to establish they’re not just tire-kickers.

elements.text: First informational call is always free. It’s about establishing fit on both sides so I don’t see it as giving away time. Agree with

!!
However, I do try to learn enough beforehand over email to establish they’re not just tire-kickers.

text:
Yes there has to be a major caveat of qualification first. Otherwise you'll end up giving free time away to anyone who asks.

E.g. if I said yes to every call request I get on LinkedIn, I'd spent a working week per month on calls.

elements.text: Yes there has to be a major caveat of qualification first. Otherwise you'll end up giving free time away to anyone who asks.

text: Nope! If there's ongoing calls needed once we've begun the engagement, of course they're billable, but first, second, third interaction is just navigating the engagement and business. I also think that face to face calls are an opportunity for the client to see who you really are and get to understand your personality which forges stronger working relationships.

elements.text: Nope! If there's ongoing calls needed once we've begun the engagement, of course they're billable, but first, second, third interaction is just navigating the engagement and business. I also think that face to face calls are an opportunity for the client to see who you really are and get to understand your personality which forges stronger working relationships.

text: I don’t charge for initial calls, but I always make sure we’re in the same ballpark for pricing and availability via email/LinkedIn messages before scheduling a call. I have charged an hourly rate for compiling in-depth proposals, what I think of as “content roadmaps”, that take more than 30 minutes to put together.

elements.text: I don’t charge for initial calls, but I always make sure we’re in the same ballpark for pricing and availability via email/LinkedIn messages before scheduling a call. I have charged an hourly rate for compiling in-depth proposals, what I think of as “content roadmaps”, that take more than 30 minutes to put together.

text: Hi all! Just launched a <https://rachel.pallet.com/jobs|content and brand marketing job board on Pallet> with a talent collective. There’s a bunch of cool roles on there, including freelance ones! Feel free to apply to the talent collective to hear about fire opportunities :boom:

text:
<@U02SU2BECCA>, bit of a work in progress. For the first 250 leads, I hired someone on Upwork to just go to capterra, and get me 25 leads in each of the top 10 categories using tools like <http://apollo.io|apollo.io>. 

I've just hired someone else to get me 400 more leads. This time, I had her find me FUNDED software companies using crunch base. In the first tranche, I learned (to my surprise) that lots of s/w companies are basically small businesses. Who knew! So we will see how this next set goes.

text: Thanks for sharing. That's the route I've been considering, just need to figure out the right source and criteria to use. Hope it works well for you!

elements.text: Thanks for sharing. That's the route I've been considering, just need to figure out the right source and criteria to use. Hope it works well for you!

text: Thanks, it's definitely not something I'm going to crack on the first (or second) go. I don't know about you tho, but for me, the ONLY way I can ever get better at something is by just doing it poorly and then iterating. So I'll probably have a better lead qualification system in a year from now, but right now it's early days so I'm going very broad. Once I have more data, I'll have a much clearer view of what kind of companies are the most receptive to my approach and I can dial it in.
